contentrichtext.text: [[Image:Japanese Bush Warbler.jpg|thumb|right|250px|The [[Japanese Bush-warbler]] (''Cettia diphone'') probably belongs in a different genus.]] '''Bush-warblers''' (or '''Bush Warblers''') are small [[insectivorous]] [[songbird]]s belonging to the [[genera]] ''[[Cettia]]'' and ''[[Bradypterus]]''. They were formerly placed in the "[[wastebin taxon|wastebin]]" [[Old World warbler]] [[family (biology)|family]]. Neither genus as traditionally delimited is believed to be [[monotypic]].<ref name = alströmetal2006>Alström ''et al.'' (2006)</ref> Due to their external similarity [[convergent evolution|convergently]] acquired by strong [[natural selection|selective]] pressures due to the identical habitat, they were occasionally believed to be close relatives. However, they belong to two well-distant families in the [[Sylvioidea]], the "[[warbler]]-and-[[Old World babbler|babbler]]" [[Taxonomic rank|superfamily]]: * '''''[[Cettia]]''''', the '''cettiid bush-warblers''' or '''typical bush-warblers''', belong in the [[Cettiidae]], an ancient sylvioid lineage related to [[Aegithalidae|long-tailed tits]].<ref name = alströmetal2006 /> * '''''[[Bradypterus]]''''', the '''megalurid bush-warblers''', belong to in the [[Megaluridae]], the grass-warbler family which is closely related to the [[Malagasy warbler]]s and the peculiar [[Black-capped Donacobius]] from [[South America]], formerly believed to be an aberrant [[wren]].<ref name = alströmetal2006 /> ==Footnotes== {{Reflist}} == References == * {{aut|Alström, P.; Ericson, P.G.P.; Olsson, U. & Sundberg, P.}} (2006): Phylogeny and classification of the avian superfamily Sylvioidea. ''[[Molecular Phylogenetics and Evolution|Mol. Phylogenet. Evol.]]'' '''38'''(2): 381–397. <small>{{doi|10.1016/j.ympev.2005.05.015}} PMID 16054402</small> [http://www.nrm.se/download/18.4e1d3ca810c24ddc70380001143/Alström+et+al+Sylvioidea+MPEV+2006.pdf PDF fulltext] [[Category:Cettia|*]] [[Category:Bradypterus|*]] [[Category:Bird genera]] [[fr:Cettia]] [[hu:Bradypterus]]
